docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Lucy Komisar's July 2 Op-Ed article, ''U.S. Duty to Uruguay,'' erroneously depicts U.S. policy toward that country.  It is incorrect to say the United States no longer works on behalf of human-rights cases there.
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Lucy Komisar's July 2 Op-Ed article, ''U.S. Duty to Uruguay,'' erroneously depicts U.S. policy toward that country. It is incorrect to say the United States no longer works on behalf of human-rights cases there.

headline.main: THE U.S. INTEREST IN URUGUAY'S FUTURE

docs.snippet: Chile has signed an agreement for a $1.3 billion seven-year loan from commercial banks to its central bank, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said in New York yesterday.   The new credit will help Chile meet payments on its $17 billion foreign...
docs.lead_paragraph: Chile has signed an agreement for a $1.3 billion seven-year loan from commercial banks to its central bank, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said in New York yesterday. The new credit will help Chile meet payments on its $17 billion foreign debt. Payments of $3.4 billion, due this year, have already been postponed.

docs.snippet: The Treasury announced that it will sell to the public the 14.4 million Chrysler stock purchase warrants it holds. The sale, which would be one of the biggest of its kind in 20 years, should bring the Government a profit of at least $250 million,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Treasury announced that it will sell to the public the 14.4 million Chrysler stock purchase warrants it holds. The sale, which would be one of the biggest of its kind in 20 years, should bring the Government a profit of at least $250 million, officials said. The Government received the warrants as part of the loan guarantee accord that saved the company from bankruptcy three years ago. (Page 1.) Du Pont earnings rose 9.7 percent for the second quarter. Aetna Life's profits fell 0.7 percent and Superior Oil's net dropped 52.3 percent. Kaiser Steel's losses widened to $7.7 million, and Western Airlines posted a $23.8 million loss. (35.)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams's carefully crafted letter, which you published on July 19, objects to Lucy Komisar's July 2 Op-Ed article, ''U.S. Duty to Uruguay.'' Secretary Abrams claims that the ''evidence we have...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams's carefully crafted letter, which you published on July 19, objects to Lucy Komisar's July 2 Op-Ed article, ''U.S. Duty to Uruguay.'' Secretary Abrams claims that the ''evidence we have seen'' doesn't support her assessment that the Uruguayan military wants to deny political liberty while allowing a hollow form of democracy.et the Uruguayan armed forces' 1983 constitutional project calls for restrictions on free speech, on unions, on political parties.

docs.snippet: Compared to Mexico and Brazil, where tens of billions of dollars are involved, the numbers were not very large. But a spate of reschedulings, refinancings or new loan agreements last week for six different countries underscored the international...
docs.lead_paragraph: Compared to Mexico and Brazil, where tens of billions of dollars are involved, the numbers were not very large. But a spate of reschedulings, refinancings or new loan agreements last week for six different countries underscored the international dimensions of the debt crisis. ''In a way it was a coincidence that so much happened last week,'' said Robert D. Hormats, a vice president of Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''But so many countries are in the process of renegotiating and rescheduling their debts that it is not altogether surprising.''

docs.snippet: Jan Stephenson, the 31-year-old Australian who said she liked hot weather and was used to it, nearly wilted at the finish but held on to win the 38th annual United States Women's Open championship today by one shot over JoAnne Carner and Patty...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jan Stephenson, the 31-year-old Australian who said she liked hot weather and was used to it, nearly wilted at the finish but held on to win the 38th annual United States Women's Open championship today by one shot over JoAnne Carner and Patty Sheehan. With a bogey at each of the last two holes ''because I was choking and so nervous,'' Miss Stephenson shot three- over-par 74 in the final round at Cedar Ridge Country Club for a 72-hole score of six-over 290, the highest winning score in an Open in six years. She thus became the third foreign-born golfer to win a United States Women's Open and the first since Catherine Lacoste of France, an amateur, won in 1967. Fay Crocker of Uruguay won in 1955.

docs.snippet: The military Government has decreed that political parties must limit their activities to internal organization and has prohibited any form of unauthorized propaganda.   In addition, the authorities issued a resolution empowering them to prohibit any...
docs.lead_paragraph: The military Government has decreed that political parties must limit their activities to internal organization and has prohibited any form of unauthorized propaganda. In addition, the authorities issued a resolution empowering them to prohibit any form of political activity, including barring the right to vote for two years for those ''who through disorderly conduct or other actions or omissions disturb the public order.''

headline.main: URUGUAYAN JUNTA ISSUES BAN ON POLITICAL ACTIVITY

docs.snippet: WILLIE COLON, Hector Lavoe and Yomo Toro, the headliners in tomorrow night's pop concert at Pier 84, 12th Avenue and 45th Street, once made an album together called ''The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.'' Which was which?   ''We had a hard time fighting...
docs.lead_paragraph: WILLIE COLON, Hector Lavoe and Yomo Toro, the headliners in tomorrow night's pop concert at Pier 84, 12th Avenue and 45th Street, once made an album together called ''The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.'' Which was which? ''We had a hard time fighting over which one of us was going to be the Ugly,'' Mr. Colon recalled the other day. Since the covers of Mr. Colon's early salsa albums depicted him as ''El Malo,'' a street-hoodlum type, he was obviously ''the Bad.'' The rotund, good-humored Mr. Toro, a virtuoso of the 10-string guitarlike instrument known as the cuatro, had recently enjoyed commercial success with an album of Christmas songs played and sung in an updated version of the traditional Puerto Rican jibaro or hill-country style. He could only be ''the Good.'' That left Mr. Lavoe, whose soulful, mellifluous vocals and Latin-lover looks had made him the heartthrob of Latin music, to play ''the Ugly.''

headline.main: COLON, LAVOE AND TORO WITH VARIATIONS ON SALASA

docs.snippet: The police arrested about 150 people during Saturday night's demonstrations against Uruguay's military Government, police sources said today.
docs.lead_paragraph: The police arrested about 150 people during Saturday night's demonstrations against Uruguay's military Government, police sources said today.

docs.snippet: Adolfo Perez Esquivel, the Argentine Nobel Peace Prize winner, was denied entry to Uruguay by the military Government today, police sources said.
docs.lead_paragraph: Adolfo Perez Esquivel, the Argentine Nobel Peace Prize winner, was denied entry to Uruguay by the military Government today, police sources said.

headline.main: Argentine Nobel Winner Is Barred by Uruguay
